title: Has Taylor Swift’s music become progressively worse? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think her music has gotten worse. She seems more interested in appealing to her strongest fan base (young girls) who seem more interested in music with beats, layered keyboards, programmed drums & multi vocal tracks (all usually produced by 1 or 2 people) over songs performed by actual musicians. She now seems more comfortable performing with 3 or 4 female dancers (lip-syncing in the process) rather than performing with 3 or 4 actual musicians. Dancing, choreography, production and costumes seem to be really important to her younger fans these days. I have no issue with her conversion from country to pop to more studio based creations, but the actual songs on her first five L.P.’s are IMO stronger than her more recent offerings. Remember, “Fearless” & “1989” both won the Album Of The Year at The Grammys. “Red” was nominated, but lost to Daft Punk. Huh? I first learned of Taylor Swift around the time when “Red” (her 4th studio album) came out and her songs would pop up on the radio station that played where i worked. While I thought virtually everything else the station played, that was current, sucked, I liked everything I heard by her and went out and purchased all of her albums. I should point out I was in my mid fifties at the time. She had a great band, good songs, good production… what’s not to like? Things changed with her 5th L.P. “1989”. The songs were still pretty good, but the band/Live musician aspect was gone. The studio only creations became more noticeable on the “Red” L.P., but band performances were still there. Her last two L.P.’s (”reputation” & “Lover”) have continued this trend where “drum programming” is credited on virtually every track. Sure, songs like “New Years Day”, “Lover”, “Soon You’ll Get Better” and “Better Man” occasionally come along with an actual piano or guitar, but they’re becoming less frequent. But, alas… that’s the state of radio friendly music today. Also, I do wish she’d stop using the standard C-Am-F-G progression in so many songs (listen to ME!). Still a fan.

Taylor Swift has accumulated more heart break “scars” and it’s showing in her lyrics. Broken relationships. Every album is a louder cry for help to rescue. She writes about her life which is getting battered. She hasn’t studied great writers of the past. She has open festering wounds, not scars; that make them take on the Democrat victim identity. Gays abuse children, want special rights, more $ from the government, spreading diseases, and are normalizing genetic defective sterile relationships. VAWA makes women less safe, gives them a cdv pass to abuse men, and pays scammers; prison systems. search, “victim arrested” bulsa. Dr John David Wren phd MD forensic pathologist. Return to a residence after been arrested for a violent felony and the location hasn’t been searched by law enforcement.

The changing and evolution of Taylor Swift’s music in no way means it is becoming “progressively worse”. It simply means that it is what she wants to put out as an artist, and if someone is a true fan they will still support her and what she means to do, despite them liking her new music or if they supported her stronger country vibes. “Worse” is subjective, surely someone with strong roots in the South who likes starry Georgian night skies would think so, but not anyone with more, erm, taste.

Only if you think artists should be pigeonholed into the genre and style they started with. She is almost 30, and clearly got bored with being solely country a long, long time ago. Don’t forget that she is first and foremost a songwriter, so she is in more of a position than most to explore influences beyond what first made her famous; it doesn’t hurt that she is very, very good at it and therefore has been hugely successful. She hasn’t lost her way because she’s the one defining which way her way is.

Her music has changed in the years since she released he first album but it has not gotten worse. If you don't personally like the new music that is entirely up to you and your own taste but for me it has gotten better.

In short, no. Music is art and art is subjective. So there's no real standard for “good" and “bad" music. Her style has definitely changed over the years. So for a country / strong lyrics fan, her first albums will always surpass the likes of reputation and 1989 but recent releases like Lover bring back in a few tracks the kind of lyrics we love from her. But for a heavy pop fan base, each new music she puts out is a step up from the previous.
It depends on your music taste. If you counted it based on awards, then yes. If you counted it based on popularity, then no.
